Graphical abstract The cascade conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) using a single-component catalyst to produce valuable biomass chemicals represents a challenging and intriguing area for investigation. In this study, we present the remarkable potential of two ultrastable polyoxometalates-based zeolite-like frameworks (PZFs), {[La(H2O)3Cl0.5(pdc)][La(H2O)4(pdc)]}2[PMo12O40]·2H2O (PZF-1) and [La(H2O)4(pdc)]4[SiW12O40]·2H2O (PZF-2) (H2pdc = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate) that can be self-assembled from the commercialized raw materials by the facile hydrothermal reaction under the controllable pH environments and their cascade conversion of biomass chemicals for the first time. The structural analyses have unequivocally demonstrated the in-situ formation of Keggin-type polyoxometalates, which are encapsulated within the cationic Lewis-acid Lanthanide-organic frameworks. The syntheses yield highly stable and tolerant crystalline bifunctional PZFs catalysts, capable of withstanding thermal conditions (up to 425 °C) and a wide pH range (pH = 1–11) far better than those reported cases. Most notably, PZF-1 demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance in the cascade reactions of HMF oxidation and 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) Knoevenagel condensation, achieving remarkable yields of up to 99 %. The structure of PZF-1 remained well-preserved even after undergoing five cycles of catalytic reaction. These encouraging findings provide a solid foundation for the further development of PZFs catalysts for the advancement of biomass conversion processes. Keywords Polyoxometalates Zeolite-like frameworks Single-component catalyst Biomass Cascade conversion Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Recently, the rapid depletion of fossil fuels and continuous concern about environmental issues has greatly sparked the rapid development of sustainable and abundant biomass conversion. The valorization of readily available biomass has become critical with significant potential [1–4]. Among a potentially promising energy alternative, HMF has been of great interest because it can serve as a renewable chemical in the biorefinery industry [5–8]. In this regard, several methods for oxidation of HMF have been successfully developed to produce other high value-added derivatives, such as DFF, 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) and furan-based derivatives (Fig. 1 ) [9–12]. However, their syntheses often need high temperature (up to 165 °C) [13,14], high pressure (>2 MPa) [15,16], expensive metals catalysts (Au, Ru, Pd, ect.) [17–19] or stoichiometric oxidants (t-BuONO, NaOCl, BaMnO4 and TBHP, etc.) [20–23], which make getting the targeted products expensive and difficult [24]. Moreover, DFF possesses two active formyl groups along with a furan ring, rendering the molecule highly reactive in biomass conversions. Currently the derivatization of DFF primarily focused on its deep oxidation reaction. However, its condensation reactions still remain relatively underdeveloped due to the lack of catalysts with sufficient Lewis-acid catalytic sites. [25,26]. The condensation of DFF also could achieve a series of high-value furan-based chemicals with broad market prospects, thus, research efforts are in urgent need to develop the Knoevenagel reaction of DFF. Although Srivastava and Rapeyko groups reported the in the two-step cascade conversion for the oxidation of HMF to DFF and the Knoevenagel condensation of DFF, respectively [27,28]. Nevertheless, the aforementioned cases have encountered challenges such as low yields, the need for additional oxidants (e.g., 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxide) or additives (e.g., NaNO2), and a restricted range of applicable substrates. Therefore, developing the bifunctional catalysts with both acidic and oxidative sites for the cascade conversion of HMF is the key to a breakthrough. Polyoxometalates (POMs) have provoked significant interest because of their fascinating properties in various fields such as catalysis [29–32], biology [33,34], magnetism [35], nonlinear optics [36–38], energy storage [39–41] and medicine [42]. In the last two decades, researchers have made significant efforts to synthesize various POM-based frameworks, most of which have involved constructing charge-neutral host metal–organic frameworks with guest Keggin-type polyoxometalates encapsulated within their pores [43,44]. Despite these developments, there has been very little attention on facilitating the self-assembly of PZFs [45–48]. Hu and colleagues were the only ones to achieve anionic tetravalent polyoxomolybdate-based lanthanide-organic coordination polymers using the simple raw materials [49], but an effective method to synthesize trivalent Keggin polyoxomolybdates- or tetravalent polyoxotungstates-based zeolite-like catalysts from the simple commercialized sodium salts and their application in catalytic organic reactions is still one of the formidable challenges. In this context, two robust PZFs materials, {[La(H2O)3Cl0.5(pdc)][La(H2O)4(pdc)]}2[PMo12O40]·2H2O (PZF-1) and [La(H2O)4(pdc)]4[SiW12O40]·2H2O (PZF-2) with fascinating two-fold interpenetrating diamond topological frameworks were successfully synthesized through a hydrothermal and pH-controlled method. Furthermore, single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), elemental analysis (EA), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and photoluminescent properties were used to fully characterize PZF-1 and PZF-2. The catalytic activities of PZFs were further investigated in the cascade reactions of biomass molecule derivatives. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and characterization The chemicals used in this study were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The infrared spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 spectrometer in the frequency range of 4000–400 cm−1. TGA curves were performed on a Discovery TGA 550 in N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 20 °C to 800 °C. The UV–Vis measurements were conducted with a UH 4150 spectrophotometer. PXRD data were collected over the 2θ range of 5–50° using a SmartLab diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. The gas chromatography (GC) analyses were performed on Shimadzu GC-2014C with an FID detector equipped with a Wonda Cap Hp-5 Sil capillary column. The GC mass spectra (GC–MS) were recorded on Agilent 7890B-7000D. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Escalab Xi+, Thermo Fisher Scientific Pvt. Ltd., UK) photoelectron spectrometer with a monochromatized Al-Kα, X-ray source was carried out to analyze the surface elements of PZFs. SCXRD were performed on a Bruker-AXS CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 K. Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images were viewed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific FIB-SEM GX4 scanning electron microscope. 2.2 Synthesis of PZF-1 A mixture of H2pdc (0.1 mmol, 16.7 mg), Na2MoO4·2H2O (0.1 mmol, 24.2 mg), La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 43.3 mg), and Na2HPO4·12H2O (0.1 mmol, 35.8 mg) was dissolved in 8 mL deionized water, and the pH of the emulsion was adjusted to 1.5 by HCl (1.0 mol·L−1). After stirring for another 30 min and readjusting the pH to 2, the emulsion was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined bomb and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. Yellow block crystals were collected after cooling to ambient temperature. Yield: 39 % (based on Mo). Anal. Calcd. for C28H44ClLa4PMo12N4O72: C, 10.00; H, 1.32; N, 1.67 %. Found: C, 9.92; H, 1.47; N, 1.62 %. IR (KBr, cm−1) ν: 3416 (w), 2921 (w), 1617 (w), 1560 (s), 1438 (s), 1376 (s), 1279 (s), 1192 (s), 1075 (s), 1021 (s), 955 (s), 905 (s), 795 (s), 764 (s), 662 (s), 579 (w), 498 (w). 2.3 Synthesis of PZF-2 PZF-2 was synthesized exactly in the same way as PZF-1 under vigorous stirring, with the exception that Na2MoO4·2H2O and Na2HPO4·2H2O were replaced with Na2WO4·2H2O and Na2SiO3·9H2O, respectively. The pH value of the resulting solution was adjusted to 2. After cooling to room temperature, white block crystals were collected for X-ray analysis. Yield: 46 % (based on W). Anal. Calcd. for C28H48La4SiW12N4O74: C, 7.68; H, 1.15; N, 1.45 %. Found: C, 7.60; H, 1.12; N, 1.36 %. IR (KBr, cm−1) ν: 3451 (w), 1608 (s), 1564 (s), 1448 (s), 1401 (s), 1383 (s), 1282 (s), 1203 (s), 1078 (s), 1018 (s), 969 (s), 916 (w), 884 (s), 803 (w), 761 (s), 697 (s), 661 (s), 537 (w), 431 (s). 2.4 General procedure for oxidation of HMF The aerobic oxidation of HMF was performed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave on WATTCAS Schlenk Autoclave (WS-MSAR-250A). Typically, HMF (0.125 mmol), a certain quantity of catalyst, and MeCN (2 mL) were successively added into the 20 mL autoclave. The reaction kettle was installed, purged with oxygen three times and pressurized with 1.2 MPa O2. The reaction temperature was 140 °C, and stirring was achieved using a magnetic stirrer operated at 600 rpm for 8 h. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. The resulting mixture was analyzed by HPLC using 2-acetylfuran as internal standard. (Caution: Acetonitrile has a very low flash point in pure oxygen and it is more dangerous, please pay attention to their handling). 2.5 General procedure for Knoevenagel condensation of DFF DFF (0.125 mmol), active methylene compounds (0.25 mmol) and catalyst (5 mol%) were added into 2 mL methanol, the reactions were conducted at room temperature for 6 h. The resulting mixture was analyzed by GC–MS and GC, chlorobenzene was used as internal standard. 2.6 General procedure for one-pot two-step transformation of HMF into 2,2′-(furan-2,5-diylbis(methanylylidene))dimalononitrile (FDMMN) HMF (0.125 mmol), catalyst (5 mol%), and MeCN (2 mL) were added into the 20 mL autoclave. The reactor was flushed out by purging with O2 three times, followed by keeping O2 pressure at 1.2 MPa. When the reactor reached the designated temperature, it was then maintained for 8 h. When the reactor was cooled down to room temperature, acetonitrile was removed on a rotavapor and malononitrile (0.25 mmol) and MeOH (2 mL) were added, and then transferred into a 20 mL autoclave. The reaction was conducted at room temperature for 6 h. The resulting mixture was analyzed by GC–MS and GC using chlorobenzene as internal standard. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structure characterization of PZFs Two POMs-based zeolite-like frameworks PZF-1 and −2 were synthesized by means of self-assembly from La3+, MoO4 2−, WO4 2− and organic pdc2− ligands under one-pot hydrothermal conditions. During the preparation of the PZFs, the effect of the pH and temperature plays a decisive role in the crystallization of PZFs. The crystals of PZFs can be solely isolated at a low pH value (1.5–2.0) condition. It is worth mentioning that the high-quality crystals of PZF-1 could not be formed when the pH value was less than 1.5 or greater than 2.0. In addition, it is necessary that 1.0 mol·L−1 HCl is selected as a pH regulator and the coordination of Cl− anion and La3+ cation is beneficial to install negative trivalent POMs anions in zeolite-like frameworks. Moreover, a lower reaction temperature resulted in an incomplete reaction of the above-mentioned raw materials, with no crystals formed. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicate that PZF-1 and -2 are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic and tetragonal system with the space group C2/c and I41/a, respectively (Table S1). Therefore, we only describe the structure PZF-1 is described in detail as the representative. As illustrated in Fig. 2 , PZF-1 composes of one Keggin-type [PMo12O40]3− polyoxoanion, four pdc2− ligands, four La3+ centers, one Cl− ion, seven coordination water molecules and two lattice water molecules. In PZF-1, there are two kinds of crystallographically independent La3+ centers (Fig. S1a). The nine-coordinated La1 center coordinates with one nitrogen atom of pdc2− ligand, one chlorine atom of hydrochloric acid for charge balance and the corresponding evidences are displayed in Figs. S3 and S4, four oxygen atoms of the carboxyl groups of three different pdc2− ligands, and three water molecules (Fig. S1b). On the other side, the coordination environment of La2 is similar with that of La1, the only difference is that Cl− ion is replaced by one water molecules and formed the distorted capped trigonal antiprism (Fig. S1c). Each pdc2− ligand adopts an exo-tridentate coordination fashion. The La-N, La-Cl and La-O distances are similar to those found in other La complexes (Table S2) [50–53]. Interestingly, two La1 and two La2 are linked by four pdc2− ligands, forming a unique quadrilateral La-organic cationic network {[La(H2O)3Cl0.5(pdc)][La(H2O)4(pdc)]}2 1.5+ (La-pdc) (Fig. 3 a). The La-pdc subunit could be also treated as the double-crankshaft chain (Fig. S2a), which are arrayed in a zigzag fashion and intersect each other to achieve the 3D cationic network with octagon lattices (Fig. 3b). Such a 3D cationic network possesses a large cavities (15.7 Å). If taking the La-pdc as node, we find that this 3D cationic network is a 4-connected two-fold interpenetration dia topological net with Schläfli symbol of {43·62·8}. It is worth noting that the overall PZFs still possesses many significant void spaces that could accommodate the POMs polyanions as guest molecules. The [PMo12O40]3− anions were chelated by two La-pdc clusters via strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding between La-organic framework and POMs anions (Fig. 3c and Table S3), thus producing a 3D POM-based zeolite-like frameworks (Fig. 3d). The investigation of crystal structures reveals that the anions [PMo12O40]3− are located inside the large cavities, but the maximum diameter of the window of the cavity (6.5 Å) is less than that of the anions (Fig. S2b), suggesting the POMs are difficult to leach from the PZFs. To the best of our knowledge, the trivalent polyoxomolybdates- or tetravalent polyoxotungstates-based coordination frameworks with zeolite-like gismondine topology using the simple inorganic sodium salts have not been reported to date. 3.2 Characterization of the PZFs The PXRD patterns of two samples remain essentially identical to those of the as-synthesized and simulated PZF-1 and −2 (Figs. S5a and S6a). The IR spectra of PZF-1 demonstrate the characteristic bands of the Keggin-type polyoxometalates (Fig. S5b), with P-O, Mo = Ot, Mo-Ob-Mo, and Mo-Oc-Mo stretching bands observed at 1062, 967, 895 and 788 cm−1, respectively [54]. The characteristic peaks at 1598, 1511, 1485, 1449, 1386, 1294 cm−1 in PZF-1 can be regarded as features of the H2pdc molecules [55]. However, in comparison with the IR spectra of H2dpc, the vibration frequencies in PZF-1 have red-shifted, which can be ascribed to the coordination effect between N atom and La center. The TG curve of PZF-1 display a 3.6 % a slight weight loss between 20 and 425 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of two crystallographic water and four coordinated waters (calculated value: 3.2 %). The weight loss of 6.8 % between 425 and 770 °C corresponds to the loss of the other coordinated water (calculated value: 6.4 %). Then, the significant weight loss of PZF-1 occurs at 770 °C (Fig. S5c), indicating the collapse of the framework. In addition, PZF-2 also exhibits the similar weight loss stages. The UV–vis DRS spectra of PZF-1 and -2 were measured in the region of 200–800 nm. The UV–vis DRS spectra show one wide shoulder absorption band at 200–500 nm, which is associated with the Mo6+ d-d charge transfer transitions (Fig. S5d) [56]. The maximum emission peak of PZF-1 is located at 397 nm upon excitation at 286 nm (Fig. S7). However, in comparison with that of H2pdc, the maximum emission band of PZF-1 is blue-shifted. The blue-shift of emission may be attributed to the chelation of the H2pdc ligand to the metal ion, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay of the intraligand emission exited state [57]. 3.3 Stability of PZF-1 The chemical stabilities of PZF-1 were investigated by performing various solvents and pH systems. PXRD analyses revealed that PZF-1 crystals could tolerate most of the common solvents, including EtOH, MeOH, MeCN, H2O and DCM (Fig. S8a). Furthermore, the stabilities of PZFs were superior to that of POMs-based metal–organic frameworks, NENU-5 [58], the two materials were immersed in HCl and NaOH aqueous solutions with pH ranging from 1 to 12 for 24 h at 100 °C, respectively. Apparently, the PXRD profiles and UV–vis spectra revealed that PZF-1 retained good crystallinity and original structures under pH = 1–11 conditions (Fig. S8b, S8d). However, NENU-5 only maintains the integrity of frameworks in acid and alkaline aqueous solutions with pH = 3–10; when pH values reached 1–2, the catalyst was dissolved in the solutions. When the pH value was controlled to 11–12, there was discrepancy in the PXRD patterns (Fig. S8c). Furthermore, the supernatant of NENU-5 provided the evidence of POM leaching in the 100 °C aqueous solution (Fig. S8d). In terms of thermal stability, PXRD patterns of NENU-5 showed that it decomposes quickly at 300 °C, but PZF-1 can maintain the structural integrity at 425 °C (Fig. S8e, 8f). The high thermal and chemical stabilities of PZF-1 are an important advantage for the biomass organic conversion, where acidic or oxidative agents are usually introduced. As a result, the above finding promotes us to further investigate the heterogeneous cascade conversion of HMF. 3.4 Catalytic performance of PZF-1 in HMF conversion to DFF The selective oxidation of HMF to DFF was thoroughly investigated to evaluate the viability of PZFs. To begin, we investigated the thus-obtained PZF-1 as heterogeneous catalyst in the oxidation of HMF at 120 °C under 0.5 MPa O2 for 8 h. We screened the various solvents and MeCN was the most effective (Fig. S9a). Following that, the quantity of PZF-1 was examined, while gradually lowering the amount of catalyst, 5 mol% of PZF-1 proved to be optimal, and yielding the desired product DFF in 70 % yield (Fig. S9b). Further analysis revealed that raising O2 pressure from 0.5 MPa to 1.5 MPa significantly increased HMF conversion and DFF selectivity (Fig. S9c). Encouraged by the results, the selectivity of DFF was drastically reduced when the temperature was raised from 120 °C to 160 °C (Fig. S9d). It is worth noting that when PZF-2 was used as the heterogeneous catalyst under optimum conditions, 90 % HMF was converted to DFF. Control studies were conducted in the presence of neat Na2MoO4, Na2WO4 and La(NO3)3 with unsatisfactory conversions were observed (Fig. 4 a). Repeated trials varying the solvents, pressure, temperature, and catalysts revealed that the optimal conditions comprised the use of HMF (0.125 mmol), PZF-1 (5 mol%), and MeCN (2.0 mL) in conjunction with heating at 140 °C, 1.0 MPa O2 for 8 h, and DFF was obtained in 99 % conversion and 99 % selectivity. Real-time monitoring was used to evaluate the kinetic behavior of HMF oxidation under optimum circumstances. The conversion of HMF and ln (Ct/C0) (C0 and Ct were the HMF concentrations at the initial and reaction time, respectively) versus the reaction time with different temperature were illustrated in Fig. S10 and Table S4, and the fitted curves were in accordance with the quasi-first order kinetic equation (R2 > 0.995), and the reaction rate constant k in 403, 413, 423 K was calculated as 0.00521, 0.00634, 0.00776 min−1 based on the equation (1), respectively. (1) l n ( C t / C 0 ) = - k t Furthermore, the apparent activation energy (Ea) values of HMF oxidation are calculated (Fig. 4d), which are 28.2 kJ·mol−1 for PZF-1, respectively (2). (2) l n k = - E a / R T + l n k 0 3.5 Catalytic performance of PZF-1 in Knoevenagel condensation of DFF Knoevenagel condensation is a widely used reaction in organic chemistry to form potentially bioactive compounds [59–61]. To evaluate the Lewis-acid catalytic activates of PZF-1 and -2, we focused on the reaction of DFF and malononitrile as a model reaction with various catalysts at 60 °C for 6 h. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the neat Na2MoO4, Na2WO4 and La(NO3)3 had the lower activities for the Knoevenagel condensation of DFF with malononitrile, respectively. Surprisingly, when PZF-1 was applied, a 99 % yield of FDMMN was produced as the desired product. The solvent, such as MeCN, EtOH, and MeOH, was also screened; the best result was achieved for the reaction with MeOH as the solvent (Fig. S11a). However, using 5 mol% PZF-1 as the catalyst, the conversion increased to 99 % (Fig. S11b). Furthermore, it was found that temperature had essentially no effect on reactivity, as high conversion and selectivity were still maintained at room temperature (Fig. S11c). However, the conversion and selectivity of DFF fell dramatically when the reaction time was reduced from 6 h to 2 h (Fig. S11d). The following are the optimal conditions for Knoevenagel condensation: 5 mol% PZF-1, MeOH (2 mL) at room temperature for 6 h. Furthermore, the reusability and heterogeneity of PZF-1 were carried out to evaluate in the oxidation of HMF and Knoevenagel condensation of DFF oxidation. After each cycle of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered easily by centrifugation, washing and drying. The results showed that there was no significant loss of catalytic activities of the catalyst in the five runs (the conversion of HMF to DFF and yield of FDMMN in the fifth run remained above 93 %, 96 % respectively, Fig. 4b, 5b). The IR and PXRD patterns of the recovered catalyst matched well with those of fresh catalyst (Fig. 4c, 5c), demonstrating the high structure stability during the recycling tests. Furthermore, the leaching test was carried out under the conditions of the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, and PZF-1 was filtered out after 3 h with a conversion of 74 %, and subsequently the conversion increased slightly (Fig. 5d). Thus, the above results indicated that the 3D POM-based lanthanide-organic coordination polymer is stable and heterogeneous in the oxidation of HMF and Knoevenagel condensation of DFF. Under the optimal reaction conditions, other active methylene compounds as the nucleophile were further extended for Knoevenagel condensation. Methyl acetoacetate and ethyl acetoacetate reacted easily to produce the corresponding furyl products in high conversion and selectivity (Table 1 , entries 2–3). Furthermore, ethyl cyanoacetate was successfully converted to the corresponding desired product with 99 % conversion and 90 % selectivity (Table 1, entry 4). However, the reaction was not compatible with 1,3-cyclohexanedione, perhaps because of the larger steric hindrance (Table 1, entry 5). Following that, we tested other electrophilic furfural derivatives such as furfural and HMF, which were all tolerant with the conditions and produced satisfactory results (Table 1, entries 6–7). To further demonstrate the practicality of the catalyst in the cascade conversion of biomass chemicals, we conducted one-pot tandem oxidation and Knoevenagel condensation (Scheme 1 ). Encouraged by the aforementioned results, the oxidation reaction of HMF to DFF was performed in the standard conditions. After finishing the reaction, MeCN was evaporated in vacuo. Subsequently, MeOH and malononitrile were added and the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 6 h, yielding the corresponding product FDMMN with 99 % yield. It is worth noting that this protocol provides the easy access to convent HMF to valuable compounds. 3.6 Plausible reaction mechanism To understand the catalytic mechanism of PZF-1 in the oxidation of HMF, the control experiments were conducted without any oxidant under N2 atmosphere in the presence of PZF-1. As shown in Fig. S12a, the conversion of HMF increased with reaction time in the first 2 h, but after that the conversion of HMF (38 %) was nearly unchanged even though the reaction time was prolonged to 4 h. Importantly, when the oxidant O2 is purged into the reaction system, the conversion of HMF reaches maximum 99 % after 9 h. The result indicates that PZF-1 may directly oxidize HMF under aerobic conditions. As per the prior investigations, we speculate that a proton coupled electron transfer (PCET) from HMF to PZF-1 catalyst might be involved in the process [62], and as a result, PZF-1 was gradually reduced, losing its oxidation activity after 2 h. With the addition of O2, the reduced POM catalyst was reoxidized and the oxidizing ability of POM was recovered. To further verify the speculation, the XPS spectra of the used catalyst under anaerobic conditions were measured. As shown in Fig. S12b, the Mo 3d5/2 peak of Mo6+ with binding energies of 231.8 eV disappeared, leaving only the peak of Mo5+ with the binding energies of 229.7 eV. This result indicates that Mo atoms in PZF-1 are involved in the oxidation process. Furthermore, we have conducted the control experiments by using p-benzoquinone and isopropyl alcohol to quench superoxide radical and hydroxyl radical, respectively, and there was no obvious effect on the conversion of HMF (Table S5). These results indicate that the mechanisms of HMF oxidation did not involve traditional free radical processes. In addition, we also performed DFT calculations to gain a comprehensive understanding of the interaction between the active catalytic sites in PZF-1 (Fig. 6 ). The aerobic oxidation process involves the adsorption of HMF, proton abstraction and CH bond cleavage. The first step is hydroxyl proton transfer from HMF to the bridging oxygen (MoO) of PZF-1-Ox to form a transient PZF-1-H+ . Then, one hydrogen atom from CH bond in HMF transfers to another bridging oxygen atom (MoO) in PZF-1-H+ to form PZF-1-2H+ , concomitant with electron transfer to Mo centers to form PZF-1-Red (Mo5+). By computing the energy barriers for the process, it was determined that the rate-determining step is the abstraction of H atom in the OH group. The energy barriers for this step was found to be 0.8 eV, which is lower than the blank test (2.36 eV). Based on these calculations, it can be concluded that the [PMo12O40]3− in PZF-1 contribute to accelerating the transformation of HMF to DFF. Based on the current experimental results and previous reports [63,64], a plausible mechanism for the cascade conversion of HMF was depicted in Fig. 7 . Firstly, HMF is adsorbed on the surface of PZF-1 (denoted as PZF-1-Ox, referring to the oxidized state of PZF-1). HMF can be oxidized to DFF through the pathway of PCET, generating the reduced state of PZF-1 (denoted as PZF-1-Red). The PZF-1-Red is recycled by molecular oxygen to produce PZF-1-Ox with water as the only byproduct [65]. Subsequently, the exposed lanthanide atom, acting as the Lewis acid in the Knoevenagel condensation, polarizes the carbonyl of DFF via LaO interaction, increasing the electrophilicity of carbonyl [66,67]. Simultaneously, lanthanide atom in PZF-1 as the Lewis acid can polarize the N atom of CN group [68–72], the negatively charged [PMo12O40]3− bearing uncoordinated oxygen acting as the Lewis base [73,74] abstracts methylene hydrogen bonds in malononitrile to produce the corresponding carbanion, which is regarded as a nucleophile used to attack carbon atom of aldehyde group to generate the new CC bond. Finally, the unstable 1-phenyl-2,2-dicyanoethanol intermediate rearranges and dehydrates to form CC bond. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a hydrothermal synthesis and pH-controllable method of well-defined bifunctional PZFs using the commercialized raw materials for enhancing one-pot cascade oxidation/condensation has been effectively developed. The combination of cationic La-organic framework and ionic Keggin-type POMs not only provided excellent stability and resistance to leaching, but also address the full expression of their respective catalytic functions upon the cascade formation of furan-based compounds. Surprisingly, over PZF-1, approximately 99 % conversion and large quantities of furan-base compounds (up to 99 %) are obtained. This study sheds light on the design and synthesis of ultrastable polyoxometalates-based zeolite-like frameworks and highlights their potential for investigating their heterogeneous catalytic activities for the biomass conversion. In our laboratory, further efforts are being made to develop a POMs-based frameworks catalyst with excellent stability. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yanan Cui: Investigation. coredata.dc:description: The cascade conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) using a single-component catalyst to produce valuable biomass chemicals represents a challenging and intriguing area for investigation. In this study, we present the remarkable potential of two ultrastable polyoxometalates-based zeolite-like frameworks (PZFs), {[La(H2O)3Cl0.5(pdc)][La(H2O)4(pdc)]}2[PMo12O40]·2H2O (PZF-1) and [La(H2O)4(pdc)]4[SiW12O40]·2H2O (PZF-2) (H2pdc = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate) that can be self-assembled from the commercialized raw materials by the facile hydrothermal reaction under the controllable pH environments and their cascade conversion of biomass chemicals for the first time. The structural analyses have unequivocally demonstrated the in-situ formation of Keggin-type polyoxometalates, which are encapsulated within the cationic Lewis-acid Lanthanide-organic frameworks. The syntheses yield highly stable and tolerant crystalline bifunctional PZFs catalysts, capable of withstanding thermal conditions (up to 425 °C) and a wide pH range (pH = 1–11) far better than those reported cases. Most notably, PZF-1 demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance in the cascade reactions of HMF oxidation and 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) Knoevenagel condensation, achieving remarkable yields of up to 99 %. The structure of PZF-1 remained well-preserved even after undergoing five cycles of catalytic reaction. These encouraging findings provide a solid foundation for the further development of PZFs catalysts for the advancement of biomass conversion processes.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ self-assembly of two ultrastable bifunctional Keggin-type polyoxometalates-based zeolite-like frameworks for efficient cascade biomass chemicals conversion
